articles.title: Jupiter’s clouds are hiding something big
articles.summary: Jupiter’s swirling storms have concealed its true makeup for centuries, but a new model is finally peeling back the clouds. Researchers found the planet likely holds significantly more oxygen than the Sun, a key clue to how Jupiter—and the rest of the solar system—came together. The study also reveals that gases move through Jupiter’s atmosphere much more slowly than scientists once thought. Together, the findings reshape our understanding of the solar system’s largest planet.
articles.content:
Towering clouds ripple across Jupiter's surface in dramatic patterns. Like Earth's clouds, they contain water, but on Jupiter they are far denser and far deeper. These layers are so thick that no spacecraft has been able to directly observe what lies below them.

Now, scientists have taken a major step toward solving that mystery. A new study led by researchers at the University of Chicago and the Jet Propulsion Laboratory has produced the most detailed model of Jupiter's atmosphere ever created. The work provides a deeper look into the planet's interior without needing to physically descend into its crushing depths.

One of the study's key findings helps resolve a long running debate about Jupiter's composition. The researchers estimate that the gas giant contains roughly one and a half times more oxygen than the sun. That result sharpens scientists' understanding of how Jupiter and the rest of the solar system took shape.

"This is a long-standing debate in planetary studies," said Jeehyun Yang, a postdoctoral researcher at UChicago and the study's lead author. "It's a testament to how the latest generation of computational models can transform our understanding of other planets."

The study was published Jan. 8 in The Planetary Science Journal.

Storms, Clouds, and Chemical Clues

Astronomers have been watching Jupiter's turbulent atmosphere for centuries. More than 360 years ago, early telescope observations revealed a massive, persistent feature on the planet's surface.

That feature is now known as the Great Red Spot, a colossal storm roughly twice the size of Earth that has raged for hundreds of years. It is only one part of a planet-wide system of violent winds and thick clouds that blanket Jupiter in nearly constant motion.

While these storms are visible from afar, what lies beneath them remains largely unknown. Jupiter's clouds are so dense that NASA's Galileo spacecraft lost contact with Earth when it plunged into the planet's atmosphere in 2003. Today, NASA's Juno mission studies Jupiter from orbit, gathering data from a safe distance.

From orbit, scientists can identify chemicals in the upper atmosphere, including ammonia, methane, ammonium hydrosulfide, water, and carbon monoxide. Researchers combine those measurements with known chemical reactions to infer what may be happening deeper below the clouds.

Even so, past studies have reached conflicting conclusions, especially when estimating how much water and oxygen Jupiter contains. Yang recognized that new modeling techniques could help resolve those disagreements.

A New Way to Model Jupiter's Atmosphere

Jupiter's atmosphere is a chemical maze. Molecules move between scorching temperatures deep inside the planet and cooler regions above, shifting between different states and rearranging themselves through thousands of reactions. On top of that, clouds and droplets form, dissolve, and interact with their surroundings.

To capture all of this complexity, Yang and colleagues combined atmospheric chemistry with hydrodynamics in a single model. This approach allows the simulation to track both chemical reactions and the movement of gases, clouds, and droplets together.

"You need both," Yang said. "Chemistry is important but doesn't include water droplets or cloud behavior. Hydrodynamics alone simplifies the chemistry too much. So, it's important to bring them together."

This combined approach had not been done before at this level of detail, and it led to several important insights.

Oxygen, Water, and Planetary Origins

The model produced a new estimate of Jupiter's oxygen content, pointing again to a value of about one and a half times that of the sun. This contrasts with a recent high profile study that suggested Jupiter might contain only about a third as much oxygen.

Pinning down this number matters because oxygen plays a major role in planetary formation. The elements that make up planets and living things originated in the sun, but their proportions can vary from world to world. Those differences offer clues about how planets formed and where they came from.

One open question is whether Jupiter formed where it currently orbits or whether it migrated over time. Much of the planet's oxygen is locked into water, which behaves very differently depending on temperature. Farther from the sun, water freezes into ice, which is easier for growing planets to collect than water vapor.

Understanding those conditions does not just explain Jupiter's past. It also helps scientists predict what kinds of planets might form around other stars and which ones could potentially support life.

A Slower, More Mysterious Atmosphere

The model also suggests that Jupiter's atmosphere circulates far more slowly than scientists once believed. Vertical movement of gases appears to be dramatically reduced compared to standard assumptions.

"Our model suggests the diffusion would have to be 35 to 40 times slower compared to what the standard assumption has been," said Yang. Instead of moving through an atmospheric layer in hours, a single molecule might take several weeks.

"It really shows how much we still have to learn about planets, even in our own solar system," Yang said.

Funding: NASA, Caltech-Jet Propulsion Laboratory.

This advances knowledge of planetary formation and the solar system's origins, with broad implications for astronomy and planetary science.
articles.personality_title: New model reveals Jupiter holds more oxygen and slower winds than thought
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Jupiter is the largest planet in our solar system, covered by thick clouds and powerful storms. These clouds are so dense that no spacecraft has been able to see below them directly, leaving scientists unsure about what the planet is really made of.

**What happened** – Researchers from the University of Chicago and NASA’s Jet Propulsion Laboratory created the most detailed computer model of Jupiter’s atmosphere ever. This model combined chemistry and the movement of gases to better understand what lies beneath Jupiter’s clouds. They found that Jupiter likely contains about one and a half times more oxygen than the Sun. They also discovered that gases in Jupiter’s atmosphere move much more slowly than scientists had believed.

**Impact** – These findings help solve a long-standing question about Jupiter’s composition, especially its oxygen level, which is important for understanding how the planet and the solar system formed. Knowing that Jupiter has more oxygen suggests it may have collected more water ice during its formation. The slower movement of gases means the planet’s atmosphere behaves differently than expected, changing how scientists think about its weather and chemistry.

**What's next step** – Scientists will use this new model to study other planets and improve their understanding of how planets form in our solar system and beyond. Future missions to Jupiter and other gas giants may use these insights to better prepare instruments and experiments.

**One-sentence takeaway** – A new detailed model shows Jupiter has more oxygen than the Sun and slower atmospheric winds, offering fresh clues about the planet’s origin and nature.
articles.personality_title_fr: Un nouveau modèle révèle que Jupiter contient plus d’oxygène et des vents plus lents que prévu
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Jupiter est la plus grande planète de notre système solaire, recouverte de nuages épais et de tempêtes puissantes. Ces nuages sont si denses qu’aucune sonde spatiale n’a pu voir directement sous eux, laissant les scientifiques incertains sur la composition réelle de la planète.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Des chercheurs de l’Université de Chicago et du Jet Propulsion Laboratory de la NASA ont créé le modèle informatique le plus détaillé jamais réalisé de l’atmosphère de Jupiter. Ce modèle combine la chimie et le mouvement des gaz pour mieux comprendre ce qui se cache sous les nuages de Jupiter. Ils ont découvert que Jupiter contient probablement une fois et demie plus d’oxygène que le Soleil. Ils ont aussi constaté que les gaz dans l’atmosphère de Jupiter se déplacent beaucoup plus lentement que ce que les scientifiques pensaient.

**Impact** – Ces découvertes aident à résoudre une question ancienne sur la composition de Jupiter, notamment son taux d’oxygène, important pour comprendre comment la planète et le système solaire se sont formés. Savoir que Jupiter a plus d’oxygène suggère qu’elle a pu collecter plus de glace d’eau lors de sa formation. Le mouvement plus lent des gaz signifie que l’atmosphère de la planète se comporte différemment, ce qui change la façon dont les scientifiques pensent à sa météo et à sa chimie.

**Prochaine étape** – Les scientifiques utiliseront ce nouveau modèle pour étudier d’autres planètes et améliorer leur compréhension de la formation des planètes dans notre système solaire et au-delà. Les futures missions vers Jupiter et d’autres géantes gazeuses pourront s’appuyer sur ces résultats pour mieux préparer leurs instruments et expériences.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Un nouveau modèle détaillé montre que Jupiter contient plus d’oxygène que le Soleil et que ses vents atmosphériques sont plus lents, offrant de nouveaux indices sur l’origine et la nature de la planète.
articles.personality_title_es: Un nuevo modelo revela que Júpiter tiene más oxígeno y vientos más lentos de lo pensado
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Júpiter es el planeta más grande de nuestro sistema solar, cubierto por nubes densas y tormentas fuertes. Estas nubes son tan gruesas que ninguna nave espacial ha podido ver directamente debajo de ellas, dejando a los científicos sin saber con certeza de qué está hecho el planeta.

**Qué pasó** – Investigadores de la Universidad de Chicago y del Laboratorio de Propulsión a Chorro de la NASA crearon el modelo por computadora más detallado del atmósfera de Júpiter. Este modelo combinó la química y el movimiento de los gases para entender mejor qué hay bajo las nubes de Júpiter. Encontraron que Júpiter probablemente tiene una vez y media más oxígeno que el Sol. También descubrieron que los gases en la atmósfera de Júpiter se mueven mucho más lento de lo que se creía.

**Impacto** – Estos hallazgos ayudan a resolver una vieja pregunta sobre la composición de Júpiter, especialmente sobre su cantidad de oxígeno, que es importante para entender cómo se formó el planeta y el sistema solar. Saber que Júpiter tiene más oxígeno sugiere que pudo recoger más hielo de agua durante su formación. El movimiento más lento de los gases significa que la atmósfera del planeta se comporta diferente, cambiando cómo los científicos entienden su clima y química.

**Próximo paso** – Los científicos usarán este nuevo modelo para estudiar otros planetas y mejorar su comprensión de cómo se forman los planetas en nuestro sistema solar y en otros sistemas. Las futuras misiones a Júpiter y a otros gigantes gaseosos podrán usar esta información para preparar mejor sus instrumentos y experimentos.

**Resumen en una frase** – Un nuevo modelo detallado muestra que Júpiter tiene más oxígeno que el Sol y vientos atmosféricos más lentos, ofreciendo nuevas pistas sobre el origen y la naturaleza del planeta.

articles.title: Puffy baby planets reveal a missing stage of planet formation
articles.summary: A young star called V1298 Tau is giving astronomers a front-row seat to the birth of the galaxy’s most common planets. Four massive but extremely low-density worlds orbiting the star appear to be inflated precursors of super-Earths and sub-Neptunes. By watching how the planets subtly tug on one another, scientists measured their masses and confirmed they are far puffier than expected. The system reveals how these planets dramatically shrink and transform as they age.
articles.content:
Astronomers were surprised to learn in recent years that most Sun-like stars host at least one planet that falls between Earth and Neptune in size and orbits closer than Mercury does in our own solar system -- sizes and orbits absent from our solar system. These worlds, known as super-Earths and sub-Neptunes, turn out to be the most abundant type of planet in the Milky Way. Yet for all their prevalence, how they form has remained unclear. An international research team has now identified a long-missing piece of that puzzle by directly measuring four extremely young planets as they evolve toward these common planetary forms.

By studying the V1298 Tau system, the researchers captured an unusually early snapshot of planetary development. Their measurements reveal planets caught in the act of changing into the super-Earths and sub-Neptunes seen throughout the galaxy.

"What's so exciting is that we're seeing a preview of what will become a very normal planetary system," says John Livingston, the study's lead author from the Astrobiology Center in Tokyo, Japan. "The four planets we studied will likely contract into 'super-Earths' and 'sub-Neptunes' -- the most common types of planets in our galaxy, but we've never had such a clear picture of them in their formative years."

A Young Star System Frozen in Time

V1298 Tau is remarkably young by astronomical standards, at just about 20 million years old -- a blink of an eye compared to the Sun's 4.5-billion-year history. Four large planets circle this energetic star, each ranging in size from Neptune to Jupiter. These worlds appear to be in a short-lived and chaotic stage of rapid change, offering a glimpse of what many mature planetary systems once looked like.

Astronomers believe this system represents an early version of the tightly packed, multi-planet systems commonly found across the galaxy. Much like the Rosetta Stone helped scientists interpret ancient hieroglyphics, V1298 Tau provides a key reference for understanding how the galaxy's most common planets take shape.

Measuring Planetary Mass Without Doppler Signals

Over a ten-year period, the team relied on a combination of space-based and ground-based telescopes to monitor the system. They tracked the precise moments when each planet crossed in front of its star, events called transits. These observations revealed that the planets' orbits were not perfectly steady. Instead, the planets subtly pulled on one another, causing small but measurable changes in their transit timing.

These variations, known as Transit-Timing Variations (TTVs), allowed scientists to calculate the planets' masses directly for the first time.

"For astronomers, our go-to 'Doppler' method for weighing planets involves making careful measurements of the star's velocity as it's tugged by its retinue of planets." said Erik Petigura, a co-author from UCLA. "But young stars are so extremely spotty, active, and temperamental, that the Doppler method is a non-starter." By using TTVs, we essentially used the planets' own gravity against each other. Precisely timing how they tug on their neighbors allowed us to calculate their masses, and sidestep the issues with this young star."

Planets as Light as Cosmic Cotton Candy

The mass measurements revealed a striking result. Even though the planets are five to ten times larger than Earth, their masses are only five to fifteen times greater. This combination makes them extraordinarily low in density -- more like planetary-sized cotton candy than solid, rocky worlds.

"The unusually large radii of young planets led to the hypothesis that they have very low densities, but this had never been measured," said Trevor David, a co-author from the Flatiron Institute who led the system's original discovery in 2019. "By weighing these planets for the first time, we have provided the first observational proof. They are indeed exceptionally 'puffy,' which gives us a crucial, long-awaited benchmark for theories of planet evolution."

Losing Atmospheres and Shrinking Over Time

This extreme puffiness helps resolve a long-standing question in planet formation. If planets simply formed and cooled slowly, they would be far more compact. Instead, the analysis shows that these young worlds must have changed dramatically early on, quickly losing large portions of their thick atmospheres as the surrounding disk of gas around their star disappeared.

"These planets have already undergone a dramatic transformation, rapidly losing much of their original atmospheres and cooling faster than what we'd expect from standard models," explains James Owen, a co-author from Imperial College London who led the theoretical modeling. "But they're still evolving. Over the next few billion years, they will continue to lose their atmosphere and shrink significantly, transforming into the compact worlds we see throughout the galaxy."

Petigura compared the system's importance to a famous fossil discovery. "I'm reminded of the famous 'Lucy' fossil, one of our hominid ancestors that lived 3 million years ago and was one of the key 'missing links' between apes and humans," he said. "V1298Tau is a critical link between the star/planet forming nebulae we see all over the sky, and the mature planetary systems that we have now discovered by the thousands."

Why Our Solar System Is Different

Today, V1298 Tau stands out as a natural laboratory for studying how the most common planets in the Milky Way come into existence. Observations of this system provide rare insight into the chaotic and transformative early lives of planets and may help explain why our own solar system lacks the super-Earths and sub-Neptunes that dominate elsewhere.

"This discovery fundamentally changes how we think about planetary systems," adds Livingston. "V1298 Tau shows us that today's super-Earths and sub-Neptunes start out as giant, puffy worlds that contract over time. We're essentially watching the universe's most successful planetary architecture in the making."

This discovery provides a crucial missing link in planetary science with broad implications for astronomy and our understanding of planetary evolution, representing a meaningful advancement with tangible benefits for scientific knowledge.
articles.personality_title: Young star reveals how common planets shrink and change over time
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Scientists have found that most stars like our Sun have planets called super-Earths and sub-Neptunes. These planets are bigger than Earth but smaller than Neptune and orbit very close to their stars. However, how these planets form and change has been a mystery.

**What happened** – A team of astronomers studied a young star named V1298 Tau, which is only about 20 million years old. They observed four large planets around it that are much bigger but much lighter than expected. By watching how these planets pull on each other as they orbit, researchers measured their masses and found they are very “puffy,” like cosmic cotton candy.

**Impact** – This discovery is important because it shows a missing stage in planet formation. These planets start out large and fluffy and then lose much of their thick atmospheres, shrinking into the super-Earths and sub-Neptunes commonly seen in the galaxy. It helps explain why our solar system doesn’t have these types of planets and gives a rare look at how planetary systems develop early on.

**What's next step** – Scientists will continue to watch V1298 Tau’s planets as they evolve over billions of years. This will help improve models of planet growth and atmosphere loss. They also hope to find more young star systems like this to better understand how planets change from birth to maturity.

**One-sentence takeaway** – By observing a young star system with giant, low-density planets, astronomers have uncovered how the galaxy’s most common planets form and shrink over time.
articles.personality_title_fr: Une jeune étoile révèle comment les planètes communes rétrécissent et évoluent
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les scientifiques ont découvert que la plupart des étoiles semblables au Soleil possèdent des planètes appelées super-Terres et sous-Neptunes. Ces planètes sont plus grandes que la Terre mais plus petites que Neptune, et elles tournent très près de leur étoile. Pourtant, la façon dont elles se forment et changent restait inconnue.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Une équipe d’astronomes a étudié une jeune étoile nommée V1298 Tau, âgée d’environ 20 millions d’années. Ils ont observé quatre grandes planètes autour d’elle, beaucoup plus grandes mais aussi beaucoup plus légères qu’attendu. En surveillant comment ces planètes s’attirent mutuellement en orbite, les chercheurs ont mesuré leur masse et découvert qu’elles sont très « gonflées », comme de la barbe à papa cosmique.

**Impact** – Cette découverte est importante car elle montre une étape manquante dans la formation des planètes. Ces planètes commencent grandes et gonflées, puis perdent une grande partie de leur atmosphère épaisse et rétrécissent pour devenir les super-Terres et sous-Neptunes que l’on voit souvent dans la galaxie. Cela explique pourquoi notre système solaire ne possède pas ces types de planètes et offre un rare aperçu du développement précoce des systèmes planétaires.

**Prochaine étape** – Les scientifiques vont continuer à observer les planètes de V1298 Tau au fil des milliards d’années. Cela aidera à améliorer les modèles sur la croissance planétaire et la perte d’atmosphère. Ils espèrent aussi trouver d’autres jeunes systèmes stellaires similaires pour mieux comprendre l’évolution des planètes de leur naissance à leur maturité.

**Résumé en une phrase** – En observant un jeune système stellaire avec de grandes planètes peu denses, les astronomes ont découvert comment se forment et rétrécissent les planètes les plus communes de la galaxie.
articles.personality_title_es: Una joven estrella revela cómo los planetas comunes se encogen y cambian con el tiempo
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los científicos han descubierto que la mayoría de las estrellas similares al Sol tienen planetas llamados supertierras y sub-Neptunos. Estos planetas son más grandes que la Tierra pero más pequeños que Neptuno, y orbitan muy cerca de su estrella. Sin embargo, cómo se forman y cambian sigue siendo un misterio.

**Qué pasó** – Un equipo de astrónomos estudió una estrella joven llamada V1298 Tau, que tiene solo unos 20 millones de años. Observaron cuatro planetas grandes a su alrededor que son mucho más grandes pero mucho más livianos de lo esperado. Al observar cómo estos planetas se atraen entre sí mientras orbitan, los investigadores midieron sus masas y encontraron que son muy “esponjosos”, como algodón de azúcar cósmico.

**Impacto** – Este descubrimiento es importante porque muestra una etapa perdida en la formación de planetas. Estos planetas comienzan siendo grandes y esponjosos, luego pierden gran parte de sus gruesas atmósferas y se encogen hasta convertirse en las supertierras y sub-Neptunos que se ven comúnmente en la galaxia. Esto ayuda a explicar por qué nuestro sistema solar no tiene estos tipos de planetas y ofrece una rara mirada a cómo se desarrollan los sistemas planetarios temprano.

**Próximo paso** – Los científicos continuarán observando los planetas de V1298 Tau mientras evolucionan durante miles de millones de años. Esto ayudará a mejorar los modelos de crecimiento planetario y pérdida de atmósfera. También esperan encontrar más sistemas estelares jóvenes como este para entender mejor cómo cambian los planetas desde su nacimiento hasta su madurez.

**Frase clave** – Al observar un sistema estelar joven con planetas grandes y de baja densidad, los astrónomos han descubierto cómo se forman y encogen con el tiempo los planetas más comunes de la galaxia.
